title: Improved Fine-Tuning of Large Multimodal Models for Hateful Meme Detection
author: Jingbiao Mei (University of Cambridge), Jinghong Chen (University of Cambridge), Guangyu Yang (University of Cambridge), Weizhe Lin (University of Cambridge), Bill Byrne (University of Cambridge), ...
relevance_why: The techniques discussed, particularly the two-stage fine-tuning framework and retrieval-based methods, could inspire similar approaches in audio generation and processing tasks, potentially enhancing the robustness of models in domain adaptation scenarios.
background: Hateful meme detection is the task of identifying memes that convey hateful or harmful content using both images and accompanying text.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel framework, Large Multimodal Model Retrieval-Guided Contrastive Learning (LMM-RGCL), to improve the performance of large multimodal models in detecting hateful memes, achieving state-of-the-art results across multiple datasets.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods faced challenges in generalizing to new memes and often required extensive re-training on fresh data.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work significantly enhances generalization through a two-stage fine-tuning approach that includes joint multimodal fine-tuning combined with retrieval-guided contrastive learning.

key_innovation: The integration of retrieval-guided techniques allows the framework to leverage previously learned examples for improved classification performance on unseen data.
real_world_impact: The improvements in hateful meme detection have implications for online safety and automated moderation, potentially leading to safer online environments.
limitations: The authors note that the system sometimes struggles with subtle visual details in memes.

new_terms.retrieval-guided learning: **Retrieval-guided learning** refers to methods that enhance model learning through the retrieval of similar examples from existing datasets to inform predictions.
